articles.headline: Trump Ousts John Bolton as National Security Adviser
articles.snippet: President Trump had complained privately in recent months that Mr. Bolton was too hawkish, a tension made worse in recent weeks over Iran and North Korea.
articles.abstract: President Trump had complained privately in recent months that Mr. Bolton was too hawkish, a tension made worse in recent weeks over Iran and North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday pushed out John R. Bolton, his third national security adviser, amid fundamental disputes over how to handle major foreign policy challenges like Iran, North Korea and most recently Afghanistan.

articles.headline: California Rent Control Bill Advances, Fueled by Housing Crisis
articles.snippet: Millions of tenants would be covered by a measure championed by Gov. Gavin Newsom in his first year in office. Final approval could come Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Millions of tenants would be covered by a measure championed by Gov. Gavin Newsom in his first year in office. Final approval could come Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: California’s escalating housing costs have yielded epic commutes and a rising tide of homelessness. Now they are close to producing a political milestone: a vast expansion of tenant-protection laws that would cap rents statewide.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Luis Ferré-Sadurní

articles.headline: ‘Trump Unplugged’: A President as His Own National Security Adviser
articles.snippet: President Trump is now free to command his foreign policy after dumping John R. Bolton, the last major internal counterweight to his dealings with North Korea, Russia and the Taliban.
articles.abstract: President Trump is now free to command his foreign policy after dumping John R. Bolton, the last major internal counterweight to his dealings with North Korea, Russia and the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On one foreign policy issue after another, John R. Bolton was the in-house skeptic who checked President Trump’s most unorthodox instincts. Whether it was talking to North Korea, cooperating with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia or inviting the Taliban to Camp David, he was the national security adviser who said no.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: ‘Big Brother’ in the Sky: Cathay Pacific Workers Feel China’s Pressure
articles.snippet: Calling it “the white terror,” employees describe a culture of fear as managers fire some who have made social media posts supporting Hong Kong’s protests.
articles.abstract: Calling it “the white terror,” employees describe a culture of fear as managers fire some who have made social media posts supporting Hong Kong’s protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Mixe Lee’s bosses showed him two Facebook posts. One criticized the police for how they handled the antigovernment demonstrations that have rocked the city of Hong Kong since June. Their question for Mr. Lee, a Cathay Pacific Airways flight attendant: Did he write them?
articles.byline: By Ezra Cheung and Tiffany May

articles.headline: Trump Pressed Top Aide to Have Weather Service ‘Clarify’ Forecast That Contradicted Trump
articles.snippet: At the president’s request, Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, told Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, to have the Weather Service say it was wrong to refute the president so categorically.
articles.abstract: At the president’s request, Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, told Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, to have the Weather Service say it was wrong to refute the president so categorically.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, seeking to justify his claim of a hurricane threat to Alabama, pressed aides to intervene with a federal scientific agency, leading to a highly unusual public rebuke of the forecasters who contradicted him, according to people familiar with the events.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Lisa Friedman and Christopher Flavelle
